ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learn all about VC and startup financing, and this is really great for students who dont have a lot of background in the area even though it can feel intimidating at first.
This course helped me understand the world of venture capital in many different angles, and I was also able to develop professional skills and network through the course.

An in-depth discussion of the lifecycle of venture capital -- including fund structure, due diligence, the term sheet etc. 
Also, brief discussions of ethics in VC, social impact investing, Theranos, ethnicity and race in VC, founders agreements etc.
Venture Capital, intersection of business and engineering, inner workings of deals, insights on the work and culture of Venture Capital
Great foundational VC knowledge.

An incredible level of insight into the people, numbers, ethical issues and innovations that underpin an industry everyone should care about. I learned so very much about new things, and also feel like old knowledge about VC was refined with new terminology, data and approaches to thinking about things. Its a community of brilliant students led by an equally brilliant and generous professor. Im going to miss this. Take this class if you can.

I learned the basics of venture capital from finding good deals, diligence, theses vs themes, fund structure, and communicating with LPs. I also had the opportunity to hear from VC professionals about their experiences.

a survey of venture capital: history & origins, VC investment thesis development, sourcing, due diligence, term sheets, portfolio construction, LP perspective, deal postmortem, social impact investing, diversity in VC, engineering in VC, ethics in VC
Great intro to VC and the people behind it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Loved when we had guest speaker (some were much cooler than others). Felt that towards the end of the course, the material got less interesting/somewhat repetitive. But overall, the course readings are amazing (e.g., Venture Deals, HBS Case Studies and more!). If you are interested in entrepreneurship or VC, take this class!!

I think the course itself was well structured for learning and the mditerm assignment provided useful feedback on my progress. I did feel at times like the other students in the class who participated the most were way more informed than I was and so I wasnt always comfortable speaking up in class, though.

The strength is the content -- it is a unique offering among college courses and helps you network and foster connections with guest speakers and VCs. 
Dean Torres obviously cares very much about his students and their learning. 
Weaknesses: the class conversations were dominated by a few loud-spoken individuals. The final paper is so open ended (there is literally no prompt) and office hours, while helpful, should not be the only way to workshop your topic. I wish there had been class time devoted to discussions of final papers (small group breakouts, etc). We also never got feedback on our final paper proposals, so I'm not sure why we did those.

Strengths: a variety of topics covered; many interesting guest speakers; loved the final project / paper
Weaknesses: none!
Professor Torres was such an asset to this class. The syllabus was varied and covered the basics to more specific topics. Great student led class.

I couldnt possibly suggest any improvements  except to perhaps do some more community-building activities earlier in the semester!

Besides that, sensational.

Strengths is the breadth of material we covered and the perspectives of the guest speakers. A weakness was how little time we spent in class actually practicing the concepts of VC and it could be improved by focusing on different strategies that are effective sourcing strategies.
Very well structured. Great teaching. Discussions always engaging. Workload ideal.

There were two distinct types of students in this class. One, students who already knew a lot about VC and were pursuing it full-time after graduation. Two, students who did not know much and were along for the ride.

Strengths very interactive. I enjoyed the class trips and getting to know my peers. Professor Torres was very accessible and easy to talk to. 
A weakness was that we didn't fit that comfortably all of us in Tsai. maybe 2 or 3 people smaller woud've been better for engagement over all

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: ABSOLUTELY!!

I recommend to students interested in VC and entrepreneurship who are ready for a very engaged time in a pretty intense context (and who are confident speaking/communicating in a group that is likely pretty assertive and sometimes tech/finance bro-y.)
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in VC, entrepreneurship, or even just tech industry in general!

Yes! If you have any interest in startups or potentially working in venture capital, definitely take this course! Dean Torres is an amazing professor who is incredibly helpful and willing to talk to you about VC, the opportunities, his experience, etc. Also, you form a great cohort of friends in the class as well!
Yes! One of the very few practical classes offered at Yale.
Wholeheartedly.

I would certainly recommend this course to someone who is looking to get insight into the asset class of VC and who is largely unfamiliar with the material. This is also a helpful class for someone to take who I looking to meet like minded individuals interested in VC, technology, or entrepreneurship as this is a self selecting group of people.

Undoubtedly. This is a fantastic course for anyone in any major interested in acquainting themselves with vc. Workload more than manageable. Dean Torres picks a great group of students. If you get into the seminar, take it.

100% take this course. Professor Torres goes above and beyond. The class discussions were great, the world-class guest speakers (from MIDAS list VCs to prolific operators) were great, the 2 after-class dinners were great. The investment memo assignment was fun to put together, and the final paper assignment was fun to research.
Yes. If you are interested in VC at all you can learn about it.
Yea
